sentence_txt: The L_Labour L_Party L_Conference : L_Policy L_review M_throws a M_spanner in the L_Whitehall M_machinery
By L_COLIN L_HUGHES , L_Political L_Correspondent

AN M_INCOMING L_Labour L_government would M_turn L_large L_areas of L_Whitehall M_upside down — but the L_party 's L_policy L_review L_barely M_considers the L_implications of its M_plans for L_restructuring L_government L_departments .

M_Scattered through the L_policy L_review are L_proposals to : L_Drastically L_alter the M_status and L_organisation of the L_Department of L_Trade and L_Industry ; L_Create two L_departments — a L_Department of L_Consumer L_Affairs , and a L_Department for L_Legal L_Administration ; L_Create a L_Department of L_Environmental L_Protection within the L_existing L_Department of the L_Environment ; M_Set up a L_plethora of L_new L_commissions and L_executive L_agencies ; M_Set up a L_Women 's L_Ministry .
Those are only the most L_overt L_changes L_advocated in the L_review L_papers .
The only L_department which L_explicitly M_escapes L_unscathed is the one which L_Conservatives would most L_like to L_abolish : the L_Department of L_Energy .
In L_virtually every L_case the M_aim of L_causing L_upheaval is L_explicitly L_declared , because L_Labour 's M_aim would be to M_upset the L_bureaucratic M_order it M_inherits .
L_New L_departments and L_quangos would , L_according to the L_review , be M_designed to M_act as M_irritants and L_antagonists within the L_Civil L_Service M_system .
But the L_policy L_review M_nowhere M_considers the L_overall L_effect of the L_individual L_changes L_proposed , or how they might be M_co-ordinated .
Nor does it M_contemplate the L_knock-on L_consequences for L_Labour L_ministers of L_attempting to L_implement their L_programme while M_rebuilding the L_governmental M_machine .

The ‘ L_medium L_term L_industrial L_strategy ’ which would L_form the M_centrepiece of L_Labour 's L_economic L_policy would , L_according to the L_Productive and L_Competitive L_Economy L_review L_group , be ‘ L_administered by a L_transformed L_Department of L_Trade and L_Industry ’ .
The L_review M_adds : ‘ What we now M_seek is a L_DTI which will have an L_equal , if not L_superior M_status , to that of the L_Treasury . ’
That M_approach would M_seek to M_knock out a M_keystone of L_Civil L_Service L_tradition .
L_Labour L_policy has L_long M_sought to M_challenge the L_Treasury 's L_dominance in L_government .

But its L_last L_effort — the L_Department of L_Economic L_Affairs , M_set up by L_Harold L_Wilson and M_headed by L_George L_Brown — L_ended in L_futile L_departmental and L_ministerial L_infighting .
There would in L_addition be a L_minister for L_Science and L_Technology at the L_newly M_supreme L_DTI , with L_responsibility for M_determing L_investment in L_research .
There is no M_mention in the L_education L_policy of how that might L_affect the L_Department of L_Education and L_Science .
But while the L_DTI would M_override the L_Treasury , a L_new ‘ M_powerful L_Department of L_Consumer L_Affairs ’ would M_antagonise the L_DTI .
It would be M_headed by ‘ a L_minister of L_Cabinet M_rank ’ and M_act as ‘ the L_consumers ’ M_voice with other L_government L_departments ' .
Its L_remit for L_inter-departmental M_intrusion would be M_wide , with ‘ a M_watching M_brief over L_government L_action ’ and the M_ability to L_initiate L_consumer L_legislation .
Only the L_Women 's L_Ministry would be M_given L_equal L_license .
It would be M_able to ‘ M_require each L_government L_department to L_review its L_policies , L_practices , and L_existing and L_proposed L_legislation ’ .
While L_new L_departments are M_born and L_others M_extended , one of the M_oldest — the L_Home L_Office — would L_become a M_shadow of its M_present M_self .

L_Labour 's L_proposed L_Department for L_Legal L_Administration would M_take over L_responsibility for L_courts and L_tribunals ; L_court L_procedures ; L_organisation , L_training and L_appointment of the L_legal L_profession , L_magistracy and L_judiciary ; L_legal L_aid ; L_legal L_services ; and the L_Sentencing L_Council .
That would M_leave the L_Home L_Office with L_policing , L_penal L_policy and the L_criminal L_law .
L_Responsibility for the L_Sex L_Discrimination L_Act , the L_Equal L_Pay L_Act and the L_Equal L_Opportunities L_Commission would be M_given to the L_Women 's L_Ministry .
The L_concept of a L_minister having L_Cabinet M_rank — and L_therefore L_implicitly not being a M_member of the L_Cabinet M_proper — L_crops up again on L_environment .
A ‘ L_new L_Minister of L_Environmental L_Protection ’ would M_operate inside the L_DoE .
That could M_work — though it is L_easy to L_imagine M_conflicts of M_interest with the L_housing and L_planning L_functions of the L_department .
More L_problematic will be L_Labour 's M_plan for the L_Ministry of L_Agriculture , L_Fisheries and L_Food .
‘ The L_priority of L_MAFF must L_become L_food , not L_farming , ’ the L_policy L_review M_says .
‘ Its L_main M_concerns would L_become L_food and the L_people who L_consume it , not L_farming and those who L_produce it . ’
But the L_regulatory L_functions over the L_food L_industry , now M_split between L_MAFF and the L_Department of L_Health , would M_transfer to a L_new L_Food M_Standards L_Agency .
That is the L_first of L_many L_agencies , L_executives , L_commissions , and other L_quango-like M_bodies M_recommended by the L_review .
In some L_cases L_Labour 's L_quangos M_merge L_existing L_ones , or M_replace L_well-established M_bodies .
The L_funding of M_higher L_education would L_become the L_responsibility of one M_body , L_rather than two .
L_Labour 's L_Quality L_Commission would M_replace the L_Audit L_Commission .

But there would be L_new L_regulatory L_commissions and L_consumer L_councils for every L_utility , along with L_ombudsmen , and L_public M_interest L_commissioners L_appointed by the L_Secretary of L_State .

There would be L_Skills L_UK — a L_locally L_structured L_training L_commission — a M_Fair L_Wages L_Commission , a L_Health L_Technology L_Commission , a L_Health L_Quality L_Commission , an L_Education M_Standards L_Council , an L_Independent L_Sentencing L_Council , a L_Children 's L_Commissioner , an L_Environmental L_Protection L_Executive , and a L_Social L_Insurance L_Fund M_administered by … ‘ an L_independent L_commission ’ .
An M_atmosphere M_poisoned by L_mistrust
By L_NICHOLAS L_ROE
The L_disposal of L_toxic L_wastes is one of the most M_intractable L_problems M_facing L_industrialised L_societies .

L_Even though some of the most L_dangerous and M_persistent L_toxins , L_including L_polychlorinated L_biphenyls , L_PCBs , are no L_longer L_manufactured , L_quantities of them L_still L_exist , and must be M_got L_rid of .
But how ?
And where ?
On this L_page , L_Nick L_Roe L_visits a M_plant which , despite L_strenuous L_public L_relations L_efforts , has M_failed to M_convince its L_neighbours that it has M_come M_clean .

And L_Richard L_North M_looks at L_current L_provisions for the L_destruction of L_PCBs , and at the L_history of L_British L_involvement in a L_rather M_uncomfortable L_growth L_industry The L_security L_guard at the L_entrance to one of L_Britain 's L_mightiest L_hazardous L_waste L_disposal M_plants L_pressed a L_button and the L_gate L_opened .
Then he L_pressed another L_knob and a L_big L_toy L_doll in his L_office L_window M_dropped its L_trousers .
You had to L_laugh .
L_Yet this was L_Rechem L_International 's M_high-temperature L_incineration M_plant at L_Pontypool in L_Gwent , L_South L_Wales .
L_Hardly a L_laughing L_matter , L_surely ?
Beyond the L_barrier M_lay some of the most L_toxic L_chemicals L_known , M_awaiting L_destruction by L_fire .
What L_else ?
A L_vast , L_smoke-blackened L_furnace ; 100 L_people to do the L_work ; M_massive L_investment — the L_company M_spent £2m L_last L_year on L_cleaning up L_smoke L_emissions .

Plus a M_backdrop of L_houses M_covering the L_valley M_walls on either L_side , a L_reminder that wherever L_industrialised L_societies M_decide to M_deal with their most M_intractable L_problems , they are L_unlikely to M_find a L_place to do so which is not in L_somebody 's M_back M_yard .

L_Britain M_grinds out L_almost five million L_tonnes of L_hazardous L_waste each L_year , of which about 63,000 L_tonnes are so L_difficult to L_store or L_treat that they are L_burnt at M_high L_temperatures here in L_Gwent or at one of three other M_centres : L_Ellesmere L_Port ; L_Fawley , near L_Southampton ; and the L_unfortunately L_named L_Killamarsh , near L_Sheffield .
Five more L_incinerators L_currently L_proposed in L_various L_parts of the L_country will L_double L_capacity .

Then there are the L_imports : 83,000 L_tonnes of L_toxic L_waste L_enter L_British L_ports L_annually for L_incineration or other L_treatment , a L_figure which has L_increased 20-fold in just eight L_years .
In these L_environmentally M_conscious L_times , this is an M_uncomfortable L_growth L_industry .
L_Liverpool L_dockers L_recently L_turned L_back L_parts of a 1,500-tonne L_consignment of L_Canadian L_PCBs ( L_polychlorinated L_biphenyls ) M_bound for this M_plant in L_Gwent .

In doing so , they M_underlined a L_fact which is L_likely to M_attract more and more L_attention as L_tankers L_continue to L_shift L_toxins from L_town to L_town , L_country to L_country : the L_waste M_chain is M_long .
It L_snakes in and out of L_ports , along our M_busiest L_highways and through our most L_crowded L_cities .
L_Anxieties which are L_currently M_felt most L_acutely by those L_living near L_destruction M_plants themselves may not L_always L_remain so L_localised .
At L_Pontypool , the M_collision between a L_precise , L_scientific L_industry and a M_diffuse , L_unscientific L_local L_suspicion is M_painfully L_apparent .
L_Local L_people L_mutter and L_march , M_make L_speeches and L_throw L_things ; L_staff M_face L_sarcasm in L_nearby L_pubs ; and for L_years there have been L_demands for a L_public L_inquiry .
L_Rechem has M_responded with a L_rather M_desperate L_open-door L_policy M_aimed at M_soothing L_fears , and more L_recently by L_issuing about a L_dozen L_writs against the L_fiercest L_critics .
‘ We are an M_aggressive L_company , ’ M_admitted L_David L_Wheeler , M_operations L_director at this M_plant and at L_Rechem 's other L_incinerator , at L_Fawley .
For a L_place so L_hated , the L_Pontypool M_plant L_looks L_innocuous L_inside , like a M_cross between an L_oil L_refinery and a L_crematorium .

L_Mr L_Wheeler , an L_engineer who L_worked for L_many L_years in the L_oil M_business , is a L_pleasant , L_slightly L_worried-looking L_man who can not M_bear the L_fact that no L_one L_seems to L_realise just what M_lengths he M_goes to in L_order to M_keep the M_plant L_squeaky L_clean and M_emission-free .

In L_hard L_hats and M_protective L_glasses , we L_walked past the L_huge ‘ L_fume M_cupboard ’ where the most L_noxious L_barrels are L_opened , and L_arrived at the L_vast , L_closed M_mouth of the L_furnace itself .
It was L_hot , but not L_burning .
There was a L_fault on the L_computer L_governing the M_plant , L_said L_Mr L_Wheeler , and the L_fire had L_automatically M_shut down .

These L_pipes M_stretching L_thinly in a M_bridge across the L_service L_road M_injected a L_mix of L_chemicals into the L_walls of the L_furnace itself ; did I L_know that L_fuel was only L_used in the L_start-up L_process , after which the L_chemicals themselves L_provided the L_fire ?
L_Workers in L_blue L_overalls M_drifted around us and M_cracked L_jokes in M_gentle L_Welsh L_accents .
In the L_furnace L_control L_office I L_found M_shift L_foreman L_Keith L_Thomas and L_asked L_innocently if he had any L_physical L_problems : ‘ Not since my L_vasectomy . ’
A L_grin .
He L_lived L_locally , so how did L_neighbours M_view his L_job here ?
‘ You M_get L_sarcasm L_mainly .
A M_lot of my L_friends are L_pleased that the L_company is doing the L_job they are doing .
L_Others are not so L_well L_informed .
You could n't L_hope to M_convert them . ’
At a L_nearby L_house , L_Leonard L_Hough , a L_retired L_schoolmaster , had L_earlier L_told me about ‘ the L_fog ’ which he L_says M_comes from the L_factory .
‘ It M_blows along the L_valley .
They 've L_improved the L_chimney L_recently and it 's very L_much L_better than it was but we L_still M_get the L_smells .
And since they 've L_refused L_repeatedly to have a L_public L_inquiry into what is M_going on there we 're not L_certain of the L_safety of what 's M_coming out .
We M_get L_smoke from the L_steel L_works across the L_valley , but we L_know what that is and we 're not L_afraid of it . ’
L_Keith L_Thomas L_pressed a L_button and a L_huge L_door L_clanked L_upwards so that I could L_peer into the M_heart of the L_furnace .
L_Piles of L_ruddy-brown L_ash M_lay L_heaped on the L_floor .
L_Pumps M_sucked L_air L_inwards .
L_Heat L_shone out .
In here , they L_burn about 30,000 L_tonnes of L_chemicals a L_year , a M_quarter L_originating outside L_Britain .
The L_waste L_arrives at the M_rate of up to seven L_tanker-loads every L_day — that is seven L_lorries L_passing L_thousands of L_doorsteps .
L_Right here , in this M_gaping M_mouth , M_lies the M_end of the M_chain .
The L_wastes L_include L_lindane , L_DDT , L_out-of-date L_drugs , L_carcinogenic L_chemicals , L_old L_cigars and L_even L_pornography ( a L_different L_kind of M_pollution ) .
About 7,000 L_tonnes of the L_total L_waste is L_PCB-contaminated .
L_PCBs are so L_difficult to L_destroy , that L_Rechem 's L_emission-monitoring L_systems are L_geared to L_detecting them on the M_grounds that if you L_destroy L_PCBs you L_destroy L_everything .
This , of L_course , is a L_key M_point .
If you did not L_burn L_chemicals like L_PCBs , what L_else would you do with them ?
The L_sea ?
The L_earth ?
‘ We are not in the M_business of L_polluting the L_environment , ’ L_Mr L_Wheeler L_insisted .
‘ We are on the M_side of the M_angels . ’
L_Environmental L_organisations , L_however , M_put the M_emphasis M_elsewhere .
‘ There is no L_incinerator which L_completely L_destroys L_toxic L_wastes , ’ L_Madeleine L_Cobbing , L_Greenpeace 's L_toxics L_campaigner , L_told me .

‘ The L_crux of our L_argument is that we do n't L_need to have L_toxic L_wastes and the L_fact that M_plants like L_Rechem L_exist , L_providing L_easy L_options for L_companies , is M_acting as a L_disincentive for L_companies to M_clean up . ’
But — another but — what about the L_PCBs that L_already L_exist ?
Although they are no L_longer L_manufactured , they are L_still L_present , for L_example in L_electrical L_equipment .
No L_one could L_therefore M_call for the L_closure of L_incineration M_plants at a M_stroke , because L_noxious L_chemicals have to M_go L_somewhere .
So a M_part of the L_argument M_switches to the L_kind of L_incinerators you L_allow while L_industry is M_forced to M_clean itself up .
L_Also , how these should L_function and — L_perhaps most L_important of all — where you L_put them .

L_Mr L_Wheeler , now L_moving to the L_rear of the M_plant to L_show off the £2m L_smoke-cleaning M_section , which had just L_broken down , M_pointed out that his L_company M_achieved L_destruction of at L_least 99.9999 per L_cent of all L_materials .
The L_company 's L_figures L_imply that when you have L_burnt 99.9999 per L_cent of a 30,000-tonne L_annual L_throughput , a L_figure of 0.03 of a L_tonne M_remains .

In 1986 , L_according to M_Friends of the L_Earth , a M_survey of the L_homes L_clustered on the L_surrounding L_hills M_found that L_three-quarters of 800 L_residents were L_opposed to the L_Rechem M_plant .
‘ The M_plant should be L_relocated because it 's in the L_wrong L_place , ’ L_Llew L_Smith , the L_local L_Euro-MP , L_told me .
‘ It is in a L_valley and in a L_highly L_populated L_area . ’
What did L_Mr L_Wheeler M_make of that ?
‘ If we do it L_properly any L_spot is the L_right L_spot , ’ he L_insisted .
M_Stack L_emissions of L_PCBs were below the L_American M_standard for L_breathing L_air - 1,000 L_times M_lower than the L_British L_equivalent .

L_Regular L_soil and L_grass L_tests M_showed no L_difference between L_PCB L_contamination in the L_immediate L_area and L_elsewhere in L_Wales — though there are no L_established ‘ L_safe ’ M_levels for these .
Five L_air-monitoring M_plants had been L_installed ( he L_took me to L_see them ) .
And here were L_drums of L_chemicals , each L_labelled , each with a L_job L_number to L_check against L_sampling .
And L_yet there are L_accidents .
In 1987 , L_aluminium L_melted in the L_furnace , M_reacted with L_water and L_exploded , M_sending a L_black L_cloud over L_nearby L_houses .
L_Later , L_drums L_supposedly L_containing L_carcinogenic L_drugs were not L_opened for L_checking before L_burning ( for L_health L_reasons ) and three were ‘ L_misdescribed ’ .
They , too , L_reacted with L_water , and a M_plant L_operator was L_burned by a M_cloud of L_acid L_gas .

We L_walked past a L_tanker where a L_huge L_man L_named L_Andy L_Matthews was L_pumping L_vinyl L_acetate into a 10,000-gallon L_vat , M_wreathed in its M_sweet , M_sickly L_smell : ‘ I 've been here two L_years , ’ he L_said .
‘ My L_father was an L_industrial L_chemist and he L_said if you L_want to L_go and L_work for them , L_go and L_work for them . ’
Were there any L_spillages ?
He L_shrugged .
‘ L_Nothing L_major .
I might L_drop a L_pipe — a L_little M_bit of a L_splash . ’

In a L_large , L_prefabricated L_shed we L_wandered L_past L_stacks of 45-gallon L_drums of L_PCBs , two L_drums L_high , about 10 L_deep ; and there were L_contaminated L_transformers M_waiting to be M_cut up and M_roasted in the L_flames .

M_Back along the L_waste M_chain , the L_Liverpool L_dockers who L_objected to the L_import of L_exactly this L_type of L_chemical should be L_aware that L_PCBs are M_moving about our L_roads all the L_time .
There was no L_difference between the L_liquid in these L_drums and the L_liquid in the L_cargoes they L_refused to L_touch .

In L_Liverpool , a L_dockers ' L_spokesman with the L_Transport and L_General L_Workers L_Union L_admitted : ‘ L_Drivers are n't L_happy L_handling some of these L_commodities , but at L_least a L_lorry-driver has more L_idea of what he is L_handling than a L_docker , who could have a L_consignment and just not L_know what it is . ’

L_Yet he did not L_oppose all L_toxic L_waste L_movement ( after all , the same L_union L_represents L_workers at L_Rechem itself ) ; he L_simply did n't L_like the L_idea that M_big L_industrial L_nations like L_Canada could M_dump their M_dirty L_problems on this L_country and his M_members .

L_Driving L_away , I L_noticed that the L_vast L_chimney was L_still not L_functioning , but when I M_called at a L_neighbouring L_house a L_woman L_showed me L_videos she had M_taken of L_smoke M_coming from the M_plant , M_settling in her L_garden .
L_Certainly the L_incinerator L_seems L_well L_controlled .
L_Certainly there is no L_scientific L_evidence that L_living L_nearby L_increases the L_risk of L_sickness .
L_Certainly , L_Mr L_Wheeler L_convinced me that his L_company was M_going to M_huge M_lengths to M_keep itself L_clean .

‘ We must M_run it L_safely in the M_short L_term and M_long L_term , ’ he L_said , ‘ because if L_people are L_able to L_demonstrate that we are L_causing an L_environment L_problem we will be M_shut down . ’
In L_April 1985 a L_tanker M_spilled 200 L_litres of L_PCBs over the L_main L_Trans-Canada L_Highway on the L_border between L_Ontario and L_Manitoba .
A M_section of the L_road was M_shut for a L_week and L_motorists were L_warned to L_clean their L_cars and to L_dispose of the L_rags in L_plastic L_bags .
L_Law : L_Always L_take L_along a L_friend to L_sue : L_Litigation can L_pay off L_even in the L_unlikeliest L_circumstances .
L_Stephen L_Gold L_explains
By L_STEPHEN L_GOLD
WHEN M_things L_go L_wrong you can L_sue more L_often than you may L_think .
L_Money may not have M_changed M_hands .
L_Someone may have L_even done you a L_favour .
It does n't L_matter .
As L_long as you can M_show that they L_owed you a L_legal L_duty to be L_careful and have been L_negligent , L_damages could M_come your M_way .
There are a L_number of M_points to M_bear in L_mind .
L_Take up L_references before M_giving L_credit , L_lending L_money , L_letting in L_tenants , L_taking on L_staff .
M_Ask L_banks , L_building L_societies , L_former L_landlords , M_present and L_past L_employers .
If you L_rely to your L_detriment on a L_misleading L_reference which was M_given L_negligently , you should be L_able to L_sue the L_referee .
The M_subject of a L_bad L_reference can L_sue the L_referee for L_libel but has to M_show the L_referee was upto no L_good : L_spite , M_ill-will or some L_improper L_motive will do .

L_Take along a L_prosperous M_adviser on all L_shopping L_sprees , L_demonstrate a M_high M_degree of L_trust and M_strong L_reliance in what they L_say and you may have L_unexpected L_protection should the L_seller L_go out of L_business and the L_goods M_fall to M_pieces .
A 26-year-old L_woman L_accountant who L_knew L_nothing about the L_mechanical M_side of L_vehicles L_asked her more L_knowledgeable L_friend to L_find a L_car for her .
She L_stipulated that it must L_never have been L_involved in an L_accident .
The L_friend L_found one at a L_garage .
Although he L_failed to L_check it had been L_accident-free , he L_assured the L_lady that this was the L_case .
She M_bought it .
It had been in an L_accident and it was L_worthless .
In L_May L_last L_year the L_Court of L_Appeal L_upheld a L_judgment against the L_friend for more than £5,500 L_damages for L_negligence because he had L_owed the L_accountant a L_duty of L_care .
Your L_conservatory L_collapses as a L_result of L_negligence of the L_professionals who were L_engaged by the L_previous L_owner to L_put it up .

You can L_sue the L_professionals — L_builders , L_architects , L_surveyors or L_engineers — by M_courtesy of the L_Defective L_Premises L_Act 1972 , despite the L_fact that you L_never had a L_contract with them yourself .

There are M_strict L_time L_limits : L_generally , six L_years from when L_damage L_first M_occurred ; where the L_damage was L_initially ‘ L_latent ’ you are M_given L_longer — three L_years from when you could have L_discovered it , with a longstop of 15 L_years .

The L_US M_sets its M_compass on two L_trading L_oceans L_Notebook .
By L_Edited by L_Alex L_Brummer
L_CANBERRA may L_seem an L_awful M_long M_way from M_exchanges on the L_floor of the L_House of L_Commons over the L_European L_Monetary M_System .

Until one L_morning in L_June 1988 when L_George L_Tyson L_turned on the L_radio to L_hear a L_small , L_investment L_business L_called L_Barlow L_Clowes had M_collapsed .

L_Investors in L_Barlow L_Clowes since 1985 , the L_Tysons had L_orginally M_put £10,000 into the L_UK L_fund and £5,000 in L_Gibraltar-based L_Barlow L_Clowes L_International ( L_BCI ) .
L_Fate L_determined that a M_short while before the L_businesses M_failed , they M_transferred the £10,000 to L_BCI because of the L_better M_returns being L_offered .
In the L_days that M_followed , the L_Tysons M_found that they and 18,000 other L_investors had been the M_victims of a L_financial M_crash of L_global L_proportions .
Of the £190million L_invested in both L_funds , L_BCI L_investors M_faced a L_shortfall of up to £100million .

After the L_initial M_shock and L_disbelief , the L_Tysons L_grew L_angry — at the L_advisers who L_convinced them about L_Barlow L_Clowes , at the L_Midland L_bank L_manager who M_gave L_verbal L_assurances of its M_security , at the L_regulatory L_authorities M_responsible for the L_investment M_community and at the L_Department of L_Trade and L_Industry which M_allowed the L_company to L_trade .
‘ I M_felt it was so M_safe , they were so L_professional , ’ L_said L_Mr L_Tyson .
‘ I M_feel L_appalled by the M_way these L_professional L_guardians have L_treated us .
If you were a M_gambling L_man it would not L_affect you , it would just be M_lost .
But this was not a M_gamble . ’
Like so L_many L_investors , L_Mr L_Tyson M_found himself having to L_go L_back to L_work to M_ease the L_financial M_strain he had L_hoped to M_avoid .
L_Ironically , it was the L_Government which he L_partly L_blamed for the L_affair that M_gave him the L_chance to M_return to L_work after L_retirement .

A L_change in the L_tax L_rules L_affecting L_pensions was L_shortly M_followed by a L_job with the L_Department of L_Environment 's L_Property L_Services L_Agency , a L_post which L_carries him through to L_March and may M_see him M_stay until he is 70 .
M_Putting it as L_politely as he can , L_Mr L_Tyson L_said the M_whole L_affair ‘ M_encouraged ’ him to M_return to L_paid L_employment .
‘ I had n't M_planned to L_work at all . ’
And like all of the other L_investors , he and his L_wife were in a L_quandry .

M_Pursuing L_legal L_action would have L_cost them L_money they did n't have ( unless it M_meant L_selling their L_house which was not an L_option ) but doing L_nothing M_left them with the M_feeling that L_justice was n't being done .

So they L_compromised and L_gave £100 to the L_Barlow L_Clowes L_Investors L_Group which was M_formed L_last L_July to M_represent the L_investors ' L_interests and M_co-ordinate the M_fight for L_compensation .

That M_aside , the L_last L_year has M_brought L_little L_respite from their own , very L_personal , M_crisis .

But until they L_get any L_money L_back , the L_Tysons M_find themselves in the M_position of the M_gambler who M_gambled all and M_lost .

AT L_LEAST L_last L_Friday 's L_post-election L_stock L_market M_surge was not a L_one-day L_special L_offer for the L_professionals only .

L_PART 2 L_Sociology and L_crime
L_Explaining L_crime : L_theories of L_criminality
Most L_people have their own L_notions or L_theories as to what L_causes L_criminal L_behaviour .
For L_example , L_lack of L_discipline in the L_home , L_genetic L_defects , L_poverty , M_mixing with the ‘ L_wrong L_sort ’ have all been L_proposed as L_causes of L_criminality .
While such L_notions may all M_contains some M_elements of L_truth , they are by no L_means L_complete L_explanations of L_criminal L_behaviour .
This L_chapter will M_examine a M_range of L_theories which M_attempt to L_explain such L_behaviour .

Although the L_major L_theoretical L_explanations are M_covered in the L_numerous M_introductions to the L_sociology of L_crime and L_deviance and to L_sociology L_generally , some L_review of these L_theories is L_necessary before M_embarking upon an L_examination of L_specific , L_substantive L_examples of L_criminal L_behaviour .
As this is not a L_book on L_criminological L_theories , what M_follows will be a M_brief L_overview of a M_wide M_range of L_theories and L_explanations .
L_First , a L_word of L_warning might be in M_order .

It would be L_naive to L_expect to M_uncover any L_ultimate L_explanation or L_basic L_cause for L_criminal L_behaviour , L_given the M_extensive and L_diverse L_behaviour that is M_encompassed by the L_term L_crime .
L_Suppose , for L_example , that it could be L_proved that one L_cause of L_delinquency was L_lack of L_parental L_supervision .
It might L_still be L_necessary to L_ask why L_delinquency L_occurred with one L_son or L_daughter but not another .
L_Also , there would be the further L_question of why the L_parents had not L_provided L_adequate L_supervision .
L_Perhaps this was because of their M_poor L_living L_conditions which would M_raise the L_question of why they were in M_poor L_housing .
Was this because of L_governmental L_housing L_policy or a M_poor L_employment L_record on the L_part of the L_bread-winner of the L_family ?

M_Clearly , we are M_getting further and further M_away from the L_causes of L_delinquent L_behaviour , and it is L_perhaps L_wisest to L_think in L_terms of L_causal L_processes when M_looking at L_criminal L_behaviour .
L_Biological and L_psychological L_theories
Before L_examining the L_major L_sociological on L_crime , it is L_useful to L_refer to L_theories from M_outside of L_sociology , from other L_academic L_disciplines .
L_Thus , we will M_look L_initially at L_biological and L_psychological L_theories .
L_Biological L_theories
L_Biological ( or L_physiological ) L_explanations are M_based on the L_notion that some L_individuals are L_predisposed to L_criminal L_behaviour because of their L_genetic M_make-up .
The L_individual L_criminal is L_born so ; and this is L_usually M_put down to ‘ L_faulty L_chromosome M_patterns ’ , or , more L_vaguely , to ‘ M_hereditary L_traits ’ .
The most L_famous L_exponent of this M_approach was the L_nineteenth-century L_Italian L_physician , L_Cesare L_Lombroso .

With L_regard to the M_links between L_criminal L_behaviour and M_inherited L_characteristics , there have been a L_number of L_theoretical L_explanations M_suggesting an M_association between L_criminality and L_particular L_personality L_characteristics .

‘ L_Sure they L_tried , they L_tried L_real M_hard , but M_back then I did n't

The L_light inside the L_binnacle M_glossed his L_black

The L_School M_Framework
A Model to M_Link L_Personality L_Characteristics to a L_Preference for L_Science
L_John L_Head
M_Introduction

In L_recent L_years there has been a M_steady L_accumulation of L_evidence that L_personality and L_allied L_affective L_factors M_play a L_crucial M_role in L_determining M_subject L_choice and L_student L_success .

L_Unfortunately , this L_evidence has L_tended to be L_fragmentary , a M_collection of M_separate , L_discrete M_pieces of L_information L_lacking a M_synthesizing L_theory to L_provide L_cohesion and L_predictive M_power .
The few M_models which have been L_developed to L_date may have been L_correct as M_far as they M_go but are L_clearly L_incomplete .

For L_example L_Roe ( 1952 ) , L_Eiduson ( 1962 ) and L_McClelland ( 1962 ) L_suggested that L_male L_scientists L_often L_experienced a M_lonely L_childhood , L_perhaps L_suffering L_social M_isolation through L_illness or L_family L_circumstances , so that they L_developed a M_strong L_interest in their L_surrounding L_material M_world and a below L_average M_interest in other L_people and L_relationships .

L_Maslow ( 1966 ) and L_Hudson ( 1966 and 1968 ) M_saw L_science as L_providing an L_emotionally M_undemanding L_activity M_appealing to L_boys M_moving from the L_calm of L_latency to the M_turbulence of L_adolescence .
L_Even if these L_descriptions are L_valid they L_still M_leave M_open a L_number of M_questions , L_particularly why the same M_mechanisms do not M_operate with L_girls .

M_Arising from the L_evidence in the L_literature and from our L_empirical L_studies at L_Chelsea L_College it is now L_possible to L_offer a M_model which is L_compatible with all the L_evidence and which L_also has L_considerable L_predictive L_potential .
What we L_know about L_persons L_choosing L_science
The L_evidence for an M_association between L_personality L_characteristics and an M_interest in L_science has been more L_fully L_reviewed by L_Head ( 1979 ) .
We L_need now only M_take M_note of the most L_salient M_features .
The most L_obvious L_one is that of L_sex L_differences .

The L_predominance of L_males , L_particularly in the L_physical L_sciences and L_engineering , throughout the L_Western L_world can no L_longer be L_satisfactorily L_attributed to L_cognitive L_differences , which are too M_small , nor to L_institutional L_factors .
L_Equal L_opportunity in L_education and L_employment has not M_made L_science any more L_popular with L_women .
L_Furthermore , the L_characteristics of those L_students who do L_opt for L_science M_show M_clear L_sex L_differences .

L_Male L_scientists , both L_science L_students and M_mature , L_professional L_scientists , L_tend to be L_emotionally L_reticent , L_disliking L_overt L_emotional L_expression in L_others and themselves , and L_depending upon their L_partners in L_personal L_relationships to M_take the L_emotional L_initiatives .
They will L_also L_tend to be L_authoritarian , L_conservative and L_controlled in their L_thinking .
These L_differences can be M_seen L_quite L_early on ; we have M_found L_boys L_aged 14 L_years who were L_opting for L_science to be L_significantly more L_authoritarian than their L_peers .

L_Girls L_choosing L_science are not L_particularly L_emotionally L_reticent or M_rigid in their L_thinking , although they do L_seem to have M_low L_self-esteem in L_terms of being L_socially and L_sexually L_attractive .
We L_also L_know that at about the L_age of 13 a very M_high M_proportion of L_boys are M_attracted to L_science and L_scientific L_careers .
L_Thereafter , there is a M_steady L_decline of M_interest in L_science and this L_disillusionment M_extends L_right through the L_secondary-school L_years and into the L_undergraduate L_period .
In M_contrast , only a L_minority of L_girls M_express an M_interest in L_science at any L_age but there is no L_obvious M_swing from L_science in the M_middle and L_late L_teens .
Some further L_evidence has M_come from our L_use of L_sentence L_completion L_tests with L_secondary-school M_pupils as M_part of our L_research L_programme at L_Chelsea .
L_Analysis of these M_responses L_provides further L_information on L_sex L_differences and between those L_opting for L_different M_subjects .

For L_example , L_girls at the L_age of 12 and 14 L_years L_seem to M_take a more M_mature M_attitude to L_personal L_relationships , M_seeing their L_complexity and L_reciprocal M_nature , while L_boys are more L_exploitative .

In L_relation to the L_sentence M_stem ‘ A L_girl and her L_mother … ’ , L_girls L_often M_produce M_responses like ‘ L_often M_go through a L_bad M_patch for a L_year but once they L_learn to L_understand each other , L_become the L_best of L_friends ’ or ‘ can L_help each other with their L_problems ’ .
L_Similar L_questions , when L_asked of L_boys , L_tend to M_produce L_banal L_responses or L_exploitative L_ones , for L_example the L_parent is M_seen as the M_source of L_money .

In M_contrast , L_boys L_seem to have a M_firmer L_self-identity and a M_clearer L_ambition M_showing more L_insight in L_response to L_sentence M_stems such as ‘ My L_main L_problem is … ’ and ‘ He/she M_felt L_proud that … ’ .
Such L_findings M_give us some L_clues about the L_characteristics of L_boys and L_girls of these L_ages .
If we L_compare L_boys of 14 L_years of L_age who L_opt for L_science with other L_boys , we M_find that the L_former have very L_cut-and-dried M_views on L_many L_issues .
For L_example , they M_take the M_view that ‘ L_criminals should be L_severely L_punished ’ or that ‘ L_anyone who is L_unpopular L_deserves his L_fate ’ .

To the L_sentence M_stem ‘ When a L_child will not M_join in L_group L_activities … ’ , these L_boys M_gave L_responses like ‘ he is L_selfish ’ , ‘ he must be L_stupid ’ , ‘ he L_deserves to be L_unpopular ’ .
In M_contrast , other L_boys and most L_girls L_pondered the L_possible L_causes and M_ways of L_integrating the L_child into the L_group .
The L_science L_boys L_seemed to M_possess few L_doubts or L_uncertainties , they L_offered L_clear-cut L_answers .
It was this L_evidence which M_suggested the L_possible M_model for M_subject L_choice in L_terms of L_ego-identity L_achievement .
L_Ego-identity in L_adolescence
This M_model was L_originally L_postulated by L_Erikson ( 1965 ) and then L_developed by L_Marcia ( 1966 and 1976 ) .
L_Erikson M_suggests that at L_different M_phases of L_life an L_individual M_faces a L_particular L_psycho-social L_problem which L_needs to be L_resolved before M_moving on to the M_next M_phase .
For L_adolescents the M_acquisition of a M_clear L_ego-identity is the L_crucial L_task .
At the L_beginning of L_adolescence , the L_individual is a within the L_family and the L_school .
By the M_end of L_adolescence he or she L_needs to M_make L_choices about L_career , L_life-style , L_personal L_relationships and L_ideologies .
The L_ego-identity of that L_person is M_shaped by these L_choices .
L_Erikson does not L_suggest that the L_development of an L_ego-identity is a L_once-and-for-all L_issue .
Some L_problems about L_identity M_arise with the L_young L_child in the M_context of L_home and L_school , and L_others L_occur in L_later L_life , for L_example on L_retirement .
L_Nevertheless , L_adolescence is the L_time when L_ego-identity L_development L_inevitably M_dominates the L_personal L_development of the L_individual for a while .
The L_adolescent does not , L_however , L_need to L_achieve a M_clear L_ego-identity on all L_topics at one L_time .
He or she may have a M_clear L_identity in L_respect to his or her L_career but L_still be L_unresolved in L_regard to L_personal L_relationships and L_ideology .
In this L_article we are L_concerned with L_ego-identity L_achievement in L_respect to L_career .

L_Marcia has M_put more M_detail onto the L_Erikson M_model and L_suggests that in M_going from the L_initial M_ego-diffusion M_condition to that of having L_achieved L_ego-identity , two L_processes are L_involved : M_crisis and L_commitment .
M_Crisis in this M_context M_describes a L_period of L_intensive M_self-examination in which L_one 's L_beliefs and M_values are L_re-examined .
L_Commitment M_means that the L_individual has M_acquired M_clear and M_firm L_beliefs both about himself or herself and the L_world .
L_Figure 16.1 M_indicates a L_number of L_possible M_routes to L_ego-identity L_achievements .

A L_person may L_undergo M_crisis and L_commitment L_simultaneously and M_progress by M_route A. An L_alternative is to L_undergo a L_period of L_considerable L_self-doubt and M_self-examination in which all one 's L_beliefs L_tend to be very M_fluid , a L_period L_known as L_moratorium , before M_acquiring L_beliefs for L_oneself and L_ego-identity is L_achieved ( M_route B ) .

A further L_possibility is that the L_individual may , at L_least for a L_time , M_hold onto L_beliefs and M_values M_taken without L_question from L_others , for L_example L_parents , L_teachers , L_peers .
This M_condition is L_known as M_foreclosure .

L_Eventually these L_persons might have to L_face up to L_period of M_crisis , of M_self-examination , and so L_achieve L_ego-identity by M_route C. L_However , M_foreclosure does M_offer an M_escape M_route and an L_individual might L_postpone L_indefinitely any L_real M_self-examination by M_clinging M_rigidly to his or her L_beliefs and M_values ( M_route D ) .
L_Ego-identity and L_Choosing L_Science
We can now M_make the M_link between this M_model of L_adolescent L_development and M_subject L_choice in L_schools .
For L_boys at the M_foreclosure M_stage , L_science is L_likely to be L_appealing .
The L_physical L_sciences in L_particular , M_offer a L_conventional L_career L_choice which is L_likely to M_win L_approval from L_parents , L_teachers and L_peers .
They will L_tend to M_regard the L_overt L_expression of L_emotions , L_including L_much such L_expression in the L_arts , as being M_soft and L_feminine .
L_Science , with its L_masculine M_image , M_makes L_little L_emotional M_demand on an L_individual and L_seems to M_offer M_clear , L_precise M_answers to L_problems .
L_Opting for L_science will M_permit and L_possibly M_reinforce L_emotional L_reticence .
For a L_girl at the M_foreclosure M_stage the M_situation is very L_different .

There is L_evidence that L_girls L_tend to be L_socialized into L_adult M_roles more through their L_potential of L_becoming a L_mother and L_housewife than through their L_career ( L_Douvan and L_Adelson , 1966 ) .
L_Furthermore , these L_girls will L_tend to M_go into a L_career with a L_feminine M_image , one which L_already M_attracts L_many L_girls .

L_Consequently , very few L_girls at the M_foreclosure M_stage will M_enter L_science unless they L_receive L_considerable L_encouragement and a M_model to do so from their L_parents and their L_school .
Neither L_boys nor L_girls at the L_moratorium M_stage are L_likely to be M_attracted to the L_science that is L_usually M_presented in our L_schools .

They are at a M_stage when they are L_likely to be L_concerned with a L_variety of L_complex L_issues ; the L_meaning of L_life , the L_existence of L_God , L_ideologies , their L_emerging L_sexuality , their L_future L_career and L_life-style — too L_often L_science is M_seen as being L_purely L_instrumental with L_nothing to M_contribute to these L_debates .
L_Science , L_somehow , L_seems to be L_scarcely L_relevant to the most L_important L_issues in our L_life .
A M_proportion of both L_boys and L_girls at L_ego-identity L_achievement M_stage will M_choose L_science .
In L_fact , most L_girls M_entering L_science are L_probably at this M_stage as they will L_need some M_self-examination and L_sense of L_commitment to M_make this L_unconventional L_choice .

L_However , only a L_minority of L_adolescents will have M_reached the L_ego-identity L_achievement M_stage at the L_age when most M_pupils have to M_make L_crucial L_decisions about M_subject L_choice at L_school .
This M_model L_seems to M_explain our M_observations .

A M_large L_number of L_boys , L_particularly at the M_foreclosure M_stage , are L_initially M_attracted to L_science but there is a M_drift M_away throughout L_later L_adolescence as they L_undergo some M_crisis .
The L_preponderance of L_boys at the M_foreclosure M_stage will M_yield the M_rigid , L_authoritarian M_attitudes L_often L_associated with L_scientists .
The few L_girls who M_enter L_science will not L_usually L_show these M_foreclosure L_characteristics .
L_Effects of L_Curriculum M_Changes

The L_real L_use of this M_model M_linking L_personality L_development to M_subject L_choice is that it M_allows us to M_make L_predictions about how M_pupils might M_react to M_changes in L_school L_science L_curriculum and L_school L_organization .
We can M_consider three L_possible M_changes :
L_Delaying M_subject L_choice : L_Britain is L_unusual in L_asking M_pupils to M_make L_crucial L_choices about M_subject L_options in the 13–16 L_age M_range .
These L_decisions can only be M_reversed with M_great L_difficulty .
What L_effect would L_delaying the L_choice M_make ?
In the L_development through the L_years of L_adolescence the L_number of M_foreclosure M_pupils will L_diminish , L_hence the L_recruitment of L_boys into L_science would be M_cut .
More L_boys and L_girls will have M_reached the L_ego-identity L_achievement M_stage and a M_proportion of these will M_go into L_science .

L_Overall there would be a M_reduction in the L_number of L_students L_choosing L_science , but those who do so L_choose will be more L_likely to M_stay L_happily in the M_subject and to L_possess more M_flexible L_minds .
The L_quantitative L_loss would be M_met by a L_qualitative L_improvement .

M_Giving L_science a more L_feminine M_image : It is L_sometimes L_argued that L_science L_textbooks are L_sexist in M_showing L_illustrations of L_boys , L_rather than L_girls , doing L_practical L_work in the L_laboratory , and so L_forth .
What L_effect would a L_deliberate L_attempt to M_change this M_image have ?
It might M_make it L_easier for L_girls at the M_foreclosure M_stage to L_accept L_science so L_recruitment might L_increase .
Some of these L_girls might , L_however , M_drift M_away again when they M_reach their M_crisis L_period .
Unless the M_change in M_image was L_immense , L_boys would L_probably not be L_affected , L_science would L_still be an L_obvious , L_acceptable L_choice for a L_boy .
L_Overall there would be some L_increase in the L_recruitment of L_girls , but no L_qualitative L_improvement .

M_Emphasizing the M_applications and L_relevance of L_science : To L_obtain a L_major L_qualitative L_improvement to L_recruitment in L_science with more L_girls and with L_students M_possessing L_imaginative , M_flexible L_minds it would be L_necessary to M_make L_science L_appealing to L_boys and L_girls at the L_moratorium M_stage .
In that L_event L_science must be M_seen to be L_relevant to the L_issues which L_concern them .
The L_probable L_implication is that L_science would L_need to be M_presented in the M_context of the L_needs of L_society and L_individuals .
L_Probably a L_case-study M_approach L_involving the M_application of L_science , and the M_interaction with other L_disciplines , would be L_needed .

Our L_knowledge about the L_girls ' L_concern with L_personal L_relationships M_suggests that the L_introduction of some M_elements of the L_social L_sciences into the L_case L_studies might L_prove M_attractive .
Is it L_possible to M_change L_school L_science in this M_fashion and L_still M_preserve the L_essential M_character of L_science itself ?
L_Clearly there would L_need to be some L_drastic M_pruning of L_content .
L_Perhaps L_science L_teachers should not L_attempt to M_cover their M_subjects so L_comprehensively .
A L_history L_teacher is L_content to M_cover the L_history of one L_country or L_continent over a few L_decades .
L_Perhaps we must M_make L_similar L_choices .

It is L_interesting to L_notice that the L_Association for L_Science L_Education ( 1979 ) L_policy L_statement in L_Britain and the L_proposals on L_school L_physics M_coming from the L_Institute for L_Science L_Education ( L_IPN ) in L_Kiel are M_advocating such M_changes .

The L_difference is that we are now L_offering a M_formal L_psychological M_model to L_suggest that if we L_want to M_reduce the L_current M_encapsulation of L_science , if we L_want to M_recruit a L_different L_sort of L_student , then L_certain L_curriculum M_changes are L_needed .
L_Girl L_Friendly L_Science and the L_Girl L_Friendly L_School
L_Judith L_Whyte
L_Approximately three L_times as L_many L_boys as L_girls M_take O L_level L_physics and L_approximately four L_times as L_many M_take L_CSE L_physics .
Over 90 per L_cent of M_entries in all L_technical M_subjects are from L_boys .

This M_means that L_schoolgirls are L_ineligible for a M_wide M_range of M_courses in further and M_higher L_education and for M_entry to M_occupations L_requiring a L_scientific or L_technical M_base .

L_Female L_exclusion from L_science and L_technology , L_even if it is L_apparently by L_girls ' own L_choice , L_also M_means that as L_citizens their L_ability to L_understand and M_control their L_environment is L_limited .
L_Nevertheless , most L_schools M_consider they are L_already L_providing L_equal L_opportunities by M_neutral L_treatment of the two L_sexes ( L_Bloomfield , 1984 ) .

In L_effect , L_ignoring the L_effects of L_gender in this M_way L_merely M_reinforces L_stereotyping because it does L_nothing to M_challenge the L_definition of L_certain M_aspects of the L_curriculum as L_masculine or L_feminine .

L_Girls Into L_Science and L_Technology ( L_GIST ) was the L_first L_major L_schools-based L_project M_addressing L_problems of L_sex L_stereotyping at L_school , and was an L_example of ‘ L_action L_research ’ in L_education ; the L_project L_simultaneously M_took L_action to L_improve L_girls ' L_achievement in L_science and L_technology and M_investigated the L_reasons for their L_under-achievement .

The L_project L_team M_collaborated with L_teachers in eight L_co-educational L_comprehensive L_schools in the L_Greater L_Manchester L_area to L_devise and L_implement L_intervention L_strategies M_designed to L_improve L_girls ' M_attitudes to the L_physical L_sciences and L_technical M_subjects .
Two other L_schools were L_involved as M_controls where M_attitude L_testing but no L_interventions M_took M_place . …
The M_approach was L_collaborative : L_teachers were L_invited to L_work with the L_team as L_equal L_partners in the L_attempts both to L_investigate and M_find L_solutions to the L_GIST L_problem .

L_However , very few of the L_teachers L_even M_recognized the L_issue as one of L_professional L_concern at the M_start of the L_project , and most of the L_first two L_years was M_spent in L_establishing the L_educational L_importance of the L_issue and L_working towards the L_development of L_feasible L_intervention L_strategies .
The L_project and its L_outcomes have been L_fully L_described M_elsewhere ( L_Smail et al . ,
1982 ; L_Kelly , L_Whyte and L_Smail , 1984 ; L_Whyte in L_press ) .
L_GIST had more L_success in L_altering L_children 's M_attitudes than their M_subject L_choices , L_suggesting that it is L_easier to M_change M_attitudes and L_beliefs than L_actual L_behaviour .
M_Pupils in L_action L_schools L_became L_markedly L_less L_stereotyped than M_pupils in M_control L_schools .
They L_also had L_slightly more L_positive M_attitudes towards L_science and L_scientists and were L_less L_likely to M_define them as L_exclusively L_masculine .
Despite some L_evidence of M_change in L_teachers ' M_attitudes and L_behaviour , they themselves were L_reluctant to M_admit that the L_project had L_influenced them .
L_According to an L_evaluation L_report this may M_reflect an L_unwillingness to M_admit that in the L_past L_schools have been L_sex L_biased ( L_Payne , L_Cuff and L_Hustler , 1984 ) .

The L_GIST L_hypothesis was that L_female L_under-achievement in L_science and L_technology is at L_least L_partly L_socially M_constructed by the L_school , an L_hypothesis M_based on L_research L_evidence as L_well as L_critical L_feminist L_analysis ( M_see , for L_example , L_Kelly , 1981 ) .
During the L_project there was a M_shift M_away from M_locating the L_issue as one of L_girls ' L_motivation towards L_attempts to M_change the M_nature of L_school L_science .

One of the L_main L_gains from the L_GIST L_project has been the L_clarification of what is M_meant by a ‘ L_girl L_friendly ’ , L_science , that is a L_science which will M_appeal L_equally to the M_interests and L_concerns of L_girls as L_well as L_boys . …
Making L_Science More L_Girl L_Friendly
L_Several L_interventions were M_designed to M_make L_science more L_girl L_friendly .

L_Schools and L_teachers M_tried L_curriculum L_development to M_build on L_girls ' L_science M_interests , M_changing M_patterns of L_classroom L_interaction , L_single L_sex L_groups and L_classes .

The M_largest M_scale L_intervention was the L_VISTA L_programme , which L_consisted of L_women L_scientists and L_technologists L_visiting L_schools to L_talk to L_children about an M_aspect of their L_jobs L_already being M_covered in the L_school L_science L_syllabus .

L_VISTA M_made L_science more L_girl L_friendly in two M_ways : both L_boys and L_girls were L_offered an M_attractive M_image of a L_competent L_woman L_scientist , and L_talks M_concentrated on L_social and L_industrial M_applications of L_science , an M_element too L_often L_missing from L_science at L_school .

One L_school was so L_impressed by the L_children 's L_positive M_reactions that they L_completely L_revamped the L_science L_work in the L_first two L_years to M_include more L_social and L_human M_applications of L_science .

The M_survey of L_children 's M_attitudes M_helped here : L_research such as L_Ormerod 's ( 1971 ; L_Ormerod and L_Duckworth , 1975 ) had M_shown that L_girls were L_interested in the L_social L_implications of L_science , but did not L_tell L_teachers what the L_desirable L_teaching M_approach might be in L_practice .
Would L_science in the M_home be a M_starter ?

A L_question from our M_survey M_asked L_children whether they would L_like to L_know more about how a L_vacuum L_cleaner L_works ; L_hardly L_anyone did , and L_girls were L_even L_less L_curious than L_boys .
This M_told us that any L_simplistic L_assumptions about L_featuring ‘ L_female ’ L_domestic M_interests in L_science would L_probably M_meet with L_failure .

The L_rest of the L_questionnaire about L_science L_curiosity M_showed that all the L_children were L_enthusiastic about L_learning L_science , and that L_girls were M_keen to L_know more about L_nature , the L_environment and L_medical L_science .

Over 50 per L_cent , and in some L_cases over 60 per L_cent L_said they would L_like to L_learn about the L_human L_heart , L_germs and L_illnesses , how our L_muscles M_work , what L_food is L_good for you , L_life in the L_sea , what M_makes a L_rainbow L_appear and how a L_record is L_made .
It was L_helpful that these L_topics L_also L_interested L_boys .

At L_present the L_science L_curriculum is M_structured around L_physical L_science M_interests , on which L_boys are M_keener ( how L_motor L_cars M_work , L_atoms and L_molecules ) ; we were L_able to L_recommend that L_teaching M_build on the M_overlapping M_interests of the two L_sexes , because L_girls as L_well as L_boys L_want to L_know more about L_human L_biology and L_spectacular M_features of the L_environment ( L_animals in the L_jungle , L_volcanoes and L_earthquakes , L_acids and L_chemicals ) .

The L_less L_immediately M_attractive M_parts of L_science could be M_approached through these M_interests , for L_instance L_teaching ‘ L_forces ’ by L_beginning with the M_action of L_muscles in the L_human L_arm , and ‘ L_light ’ via the L_dissection of a L_bull 's L_eye .
When L_women L_scientists L_employ such M_approaches , and L_describe their own L_work , as L_happened during the L_VISTA L_programme , L_girls are L_receiving M_double L_encouragement .

These L_examples M_indicate some of the M_features of L_girl L_friendly L_science : it M_builds on L_girls ' M_interests , not just L_boys ' ; it L_explicitly M_encourages L_girls to M_see themselves as L_potential L_scientists , and it M_includes some of the L_social and L_human L_implications and M_applications of L_science .
Other L_GIST L_Interventions

All the L_GIST L_schools were L_mixed L_comprehensives , and at L_first L_teachers were most L_unwilling to L_separate L_boys and L_girls at all , on the L_grounds that it M_ran L_counter to their L_co-educational L_comprehensive L_philosophy .
Then L_certain L_teachers were L_particularly M_struck by the L_evidence of M_large L_differences in the M_interests and L_experience L_children M_brought with them to L_school .
L_Girls had M_far L_less ‘ L_tinkering ’ L_experience than L_boys and the M_connection with their L_lesser M_interest in L_topics like ‘ how L_electricity is L_produced ’ L_seemed L_obvious .
L_Several L_special L_science or L_craft L_clubs were L_organized in the L_lunch L_hour for L_girls only and in two L_schools L_teachers M_planned L_single-sex L_teaching .
As we shall M_see , it was in these two L_schools that the M_largest L_measurable M_changes of M_attitude and L_option L_choice L_occurred .

For a more L_girl L_friendly L_science , it L_seems M_vital that L_teachers should M_come to M_see that when all the L_masculine M_packaging , L_evident in L_textbooks and M_resources as L_well as L_teachers ' and L_boys ' L_behaviour in the L_classroom , is M_removed , L_girls can be very L_enthusiastic about L_science . …
L_Alison L_Kelly M_sees at L_least four M_distinct L_senses in which it can be L_argued that L_science is L_masculine .

L_First , the M_pupils , L_teachers and L_practitioners of L_science are L_overwhelmingly L_male in L_terms of L_numbers ; L_second , L_school L_science is M_packaged and M_presented to M_appeal to L_boys , not L_girls ; L_third , L_classroom L_behaviours and L_interaction M_operate to M_reconstruct L_science as a L_male L_activity , and L_finally it has been L_suggested that ‘ L_scientific ’ L_thinking L_embodies an L_intrinsically L_masculine M_world M_view .

The L_GIST L_interventions L_described above L_relate to three of these : L_VISTA L_women , albeit L_briefly and L_temporarily , L_redressed the L_numerical M_balance by L_offering L_female L_role L_models of L_practising L_scientists ; L_VISTA and the L_curriculum L_development which M_followed L_involved a L_limited ‘ M_repackaging ’ of L_science to M_remove its L_exclusively L_masculine M_appeal , and the L_single-sex L_classes and L_classroom L_observation M_showed how L_science M_comes to be M_defined as ‘ L_masculine ’ in the L_mixed L_school .

The L_fourth M_point , the L_idea that L_science is L_intrinsically L_masculine , can be M_sustained only by M_clinging to an L_irredeemably M_narrow L_conception of L_science and L_scientific L_thinking .

The L_industrial and L_social M_impact of L_science on L_health , on L_people , on the L_environment , a M_focus on the L_beauty and L_complexity of the L_natural L_world , are L_notable L_omissions from the L_school L_science L_syllabus .
L_Girls are not L_uninterested in L_science , they are L_bored by the L_limited M_version of it they M_meet in L_school .

One of the L_purposes of an M_extended L_period of L_single-sex L_science L_teaching might be to L_let L_teachers M_see how L_girls M_approach L_scientific L_matters , and to M_discover , what may L_well be the L_case , that L_girls are just as L_capable of ‘ L_scientific L_thinking ’ as L_boys .

L_Margaret L_Spear , in a L_different L_study from the one L_reported in this L_volume , M_found that for L_identical L_work L_boys were L_marked M_higher than L_girls for L_supposed L_understanding of L_principles , L_aptitude for L_science and O L_level L_suitability ( L_Spear , 1984 ) .
II THE L_FIRST L_CRITIQUE
L_Unity had been L_easy during the L_Resistance , because L_relationships were L_almost L_always L_man-to-man .

Over against the L_German L_army or the L_Vichy L_government , where L_social L_generality M_ruled , as it does in all M_machines of L_state , the L_Resistance M_offered the L_rare L_phenomenon of L_historical L_action which L_remained L_personal .

The L_psychological and L_moral M_elements of L_political L_action were L_almost the only L_ones to M_appear here , which is why L_intellectuals L_least M_inclined to L_politics were to be M_seen in the L_Resistance .

The L_Resistance was a L_unique L_experience for them , and they L_wanted to M_preserve its L_experience in the L_new L_French L_politics because this L_experience M_broke M_away from the L_famous L_dilemma of being and doing , which M_confronts all L_intellectuals in the M_face of L_action … .
It is only too L_obvious that this M_balance between L_action and L_personal L_life was M_intimately M_bound up with the L_conditions of L_clandestine L_action and could not M_survive it .

And in this M_sense it must be M_said that the L_Resistance L_experience , by M_making us L_believe that L_politics is a M_relationship between L_man and L_man or between L_consciousnesses , M_fostered our L_illusions of 1939 and M_masked the L_truth of the L_incredible M_power of L_history which the L_Occupation M_taught us in another M_connection .

If by 1945 L_Merleau-ponty had here L_already M_indicated the L_historical L_basis for what was to L_become L_Sartre 's L_project in the L_Critique , the L_theoretical L_problem that M_followed was how to M_unite L_orthodox L_Marxist L_concepts of L_economic L_determinism and L_historical L_necessity with the L_individualism of L_Sartre 's L_earlier L_work , that is the L_existentialist L_notion of the L_authentic L_self and the L_possibility of L_choosing one 's own L_freedom : how to M_relocate L_human L_practice within L_historical L_determinism , to M_reconcile the L_individual with the L_social , the L_idea of L_agency with that of L_necessity , or L_freedom with L_history ?
For L_Marxist or L_Hegelian L_thought , such an L_age-old L_contradiction ought to be L_resolvable through the L_operations of L_dialectical L_logic .

L_Citing L_Marx 's L_famous L_remark in The L_Eighteenth L_Brumaire , ‘ L_Men M_make their own L_History … but under L_circumstances … M_given and M_transmitted from the L_past ’ , L_Sartre L_suggested that this L_implied ‘ the L_permanent and L_dialectical L_unity of L_freedom and L_necessity , ( I , 35 ) .

L_Accordingly , he L_attempted to M_shift L_Marxism M_away from L_orthodox L_theories of an L_absolute L_determinism towards the L_primacy of a L_concept of ‘ L_History ’ which , while L_still a L_totality as it had been for Lukács , a L_process with a L_determinate L_meaning and M_end , could L_also M_include a L_concept of L_human L_agency and L_thus M_articulate the L_individual with the L_social , L_freedom with L_determinism .

L_Today , L_Sartre 's L_voluntarism is to some M_extent M_returning to L_favour as the L_result of a L_desire to M_retrieve the L_categories of L_agency and the M_subject , which M_goes M_together with the L_wish to M_get out of the L_apparently L_totalizing M_systems of L_Adorno , L_Althusser or L_Foucault .

L_Sartre 's M_stress on the M_role of the M_subject L_also M_finds L_approval because L_many of those no L_longer M_prepared to L_argue for a L_general L_theory of L_history as the M_progress of a L_single M_narrative of M_class-struggle , have L_begun to L_argue L_instead for a M_return of its L_correlative , the M_subject , L_almost as if it was the M_next L_best M_thing in the L_absence of L_history itself .

But it L_still M_leaves us with the L_crucial L_problem that L_Sartre had to L_solve , L_namely how to M_link L_human L_consciousness with the L_processes of L_history so that the L_former can be L_said to be the M_agent of the L_latter .
How could this M_take L_place ?
As L_Sartre had M_put it in What is L_Literature ? :
‘ L_Never has homo faber L_better L_understood that he has M_made L_history and L_never has he M_felt so L_powerless before L_history ’ .
How can L_man M_make L_history if at the same L_time it is L_history which M_makes him ?

L_Sartre M_considered that L_orthodox L_dialectical L_materialism M_takes the L_easy M_way out by L_merely M_eliminating the L_first in L_favour of the L_second , M_making L_man a M_passive M_product L_entirely L_determined by L_economic L_circumstances .

L_Unwilling to M_follow L_Merleau-Ponty by M_dropping the L_second in L_favour of the L_first , L_Sartre L_argued that it was L_possible for L_man to be both at once through the M_movement of L_praxis , that is L_intentional L_actions which M_produce M_material L_effects .

Its L_corollary , whereby L_praxis L_becomes L_determining L_history , he L_called the ‘ M_practico-inert ’ , by which he L_meant the L_material L_circumstances that have themselves been L_created by L_previous L_praxes and which L_form the L_conditions for L_new L_praxis .
The L_individual is L_thus both L_totalizer and L_totalized , M_deftly M_uniting L_freedom with L_necessity .

Though this M_neatly M_solves the L_problem of how L_man can M_make L_history while at the same L_time L_history M_makes him , it does not M_answer the M_larger L_question of how a L_multiplicity of the M_products of L_individual L_acts , ‘ L_totalizations ’ , can themselves be L_totalized into the L_overall L_totalization L_required by the L_logic of L_dialectical L_rationality — L_rather than being the L_arbitrary , M_blind and L_self-cancelling M_movements of , M_say , L_Hardy 's L_immanent will .

L_Sartre 's L_fundamental L_thesis , that ‘ L_History L_continually L_effects L_totalisations of L_totalisations ’ ( I , 15 ) , does not in itself M_answer what L_Ronald L_Aronson has L_rightly L_characterized as the L_question for L_Sartre : ‘ how do M_separate , M_antagonistic L_actions M_yield a L_history ; how do L_individual L_totalizations M_lead to L_Totalization ( and L_also M_progress , the M_direction of L_history , its L_truth and its L_meaning ) ? ’

For the M_whole L_basis of L_Sartre 's L_argument is that the L_dialectic of L_history is not a L_metaphysical M_law , ‘ some M_powerful L_unitary M_force M_revealing itself behind L_History like the will of L_God ’ , but the M_continuously M_produced L_effect of L_individual L_conflicts ; each L_action is in its M_turn L_subsumed as a M_part of the L_whole in an L_ever M_broader , L_developing L_totalization ( I , 37 ) .

What L_Sartre L_needs to L_demonstrate , L_therefore , is that if the M_law of the L_dialectic M_works from the L_individual M_level , L_overall it M_produces L_nothing L_less than the L_intelligibility or the L_meaning of L_History as such :

The L_dialectic is the M_law of L_totalization which L_creates L_several L_collectivities , L_several L_societies , and one L_history — L_realities , that is , which M_impose themselves on L_individuals ; but at the same L_time it must be M_woven out of L_millions of L_individual L_actions .
We must M_show that it is L_possible for it to be both a L_resultant … and a L_totalizing M_force … how it can L_continually L_bring about the L_unity of L_dispersive L_profusion and L_integration .
But what M_produces the L_overall M_direction of L_History ?
How does it ‘ L_continually L_bring about the L_unity of L_dispersive L_profusion and L_integration ’ ?
L_Sartre does not L_attempt to L_answer this L_question , M_shifting L_rather to the L_notion of a L_lack of L_self-consciousness .
The L_dialectic is the M_law that L_remains M_hidden .
At the L_moment , ‘ L_history is M_made without being L_known ( l'histoire se L_fait L_sans se connâitre ) ’ — L_history L_constitutes , we might L_say L_today , a M_political M_unconscious .

‘ L_Marxism ’ , on the other M_hand , L_Sartre L_claims , ‘ is L_History itself L_becoming M_conscious of itself ’ ( I , 40 ) : as for Lukács , it is by L_becoming M_conscious of itself as the M_subject of L_history that the L_working L_class will M_understand L_history 's L_meaning — and so M_recognize itself as the L_meaning of L_history .

While he M_suggests in L_apocalyptic M_tones in The L_Problem of L_Method that this L_process of L_self-consciousness is at L_last L_beginning to M_take L_place , and that L_civil , L_foreign and L_colonial L_wars are L_becoming L_apparent as L_different M_forms of a L_single L_class M_struggle , L_Sartre L_also M_admits that the M_divorce between L_theory and L_praxis which L_ensued under L_Stalinism has L_generally L_prevented any M_clear L_self-consciousness among the M_masses .

The ‘ M_detour , of L_Stalinism is L_thus L_formalized as L_Marxism 's own M_descent into its M_unconscious , L_resulting in a M_dream-work of L_heterogeneous L_histories that have M_eluded L_systematization and L_subsumption into the L_single L_meaning of L_Marxism 's own M_reading of L_history .

It is L_therefore , L_Sartre L_argues , our L_historical L_task to M_make it L_known , L_promoting not just the L_historical L_process as such , but L_also the L_general M_recognition whereby the L_plurality of the L_meanings of L_individual L_histories can be M_seen to M_combine to M_make one L_history , with one L_meaning — the ‘ L_Truth of L_humanity ’ ( I , 822 ) .

L_Sartre 's M_account L_thus M_sets up the M_articulation of L_history , L_univocal L_meaning , and L_totality as the L_indissoluble L_set of M_elements L_required for the L_validation of L_Marxism , L_necessary in L_order to M_save it from its M_detour from itself .
The L_problem , L_however , M_remains how such L_universals are M_produced from the L_multiplicity of M_initiating L_individual L_praxes .
If L_History is a L_history of L_conflict , how could it be both one and M_internally L_diversified without the M_inner M_moving L_principle of the L_dialectic ?

How can L_History be a L_unity if it is L_also L_conflictual , if each L_action is M_aimed at M_destroying the other and L_results in a M_double M_negation in which the L_original M_aims of each L_action have been M_destroyed by the other ?
If each L_action L_negates the M_aim of the other , where is the ‘ L_unity ’ L_totalized in the L_conflict ?
How does L_History L_constantly L_totalize itself ?

( I , 817 — 18 ) L_Sartre M_arrives at what he L_calls ‘ the L_real L_problem of L_History ’ , that is how there can be L_totalization without a L_totalizer , only at the very M_end of L_Volume I. It is not until the M_next L_volume , L_however , that he L_intends to M_show how L_individual L_actions , L_separate L_multiplicities , M_make up ‘ one L_human L_history , with one L_truth and one L_intelligibility ’ ( I , 69 ) .
Throughout , L_Sartre has L_nevertheless M_taken it ‘ for L_granted that such a L_totalisation is L_constantly L_developing both as L_History and as L_historical L_Truth ’ ( I , 822 ) .
His L_History , L_therefore , is L_always in L_process : but its L_teleology of a L_final L_totalization L_always has to be M_assumed .
He L_thus L_asserts the L_Truth of L_History while L_constantly M_projecting M_forwards and L_deferring its L_proof .
But when the L_proof M_comes it L_also M_turns out to M_rest on the L_assumption that it is L_already M_true .
III THE L_SECOND L_CRITIQUE :
‘ We are L_trying to L_establish the L_Truth of History'

L_Sartre M_produces a M_persuasive M_formulation of the M_relation of the L_individual to the L_determining L_historical L_circumstance through his L_concepts of L_praxis and the M_practico-inert ; it is L_also L_obvious to him how the M_larger L_question of L_History ought to be L_solved .
He L_asserts it L_often L_enough : ‘ L_History L_continually L_effects L_totalisations of L_totalisations , ( I , 15 ) .
But in L_Volume I of the L_Critique , as we have M_seen , he L_continually L_defers the M_demonstration of his L_proof .

For the ‘ L_dogmatic L_dialectic ’ , as he L_describes L_dialectical L_materialism , the M_whole L_question M_naturally L_poses no L_problem , for each L_person or L_group L_simply L_constitutes a L_partial L_moment of an L_already M_operative M_movement of L_totalization that M_produces them and then M_goes beyond them .

But L_Sartre 's M_dispensing with all L_historicist M_schemas L_creates the L_problem of how , between two L_autonomous and L_contradictory L_totalizations , there could be ‘ one L_dialectical L_intelligibility of the L_ongoing L_process ’ ( II , 13 ) .

He L_attempts to L_solve this through M_matching his M_account of L_contradiction with a L_new L_concept M_derived from the L_conjunction of L_work and L_labour : ‘ L_anti-labour ’ ( L_anti-travail ) , a L_category of M_negation .
The M_products of a L_conflict , as L_well as its M_residues , may L_seem L_incomprehensible L_insofar as they L_differ from the L_original L_intentions of any of the M_combatants .
L_Nevertheless they L_constitute the L_basis and L_conditions for further L_actions and L_history .
L_Dialectical L_reason M_encounters such M_products as L_undecidables :

aporias — because they L_seem to be at once the L_results of a L_communal L_enterprise while at the same L_time M_bearing M_witness to the L_fact that this L_enterprise L_never L_existed except as the L_inhuman L_reverse M_side of two L_opposed L_actions in which each M_aims to M_destroy the other .

In the L_dialectical M_perspective , we M_encounter these M_objects as L_productions which are L_human and L_provided with a L_future … L_thus they L_seem by themselves to be L_totalizations in L_process .

This M_means that L_first , they M_lead to L_results , and L_second , that the M_internal M_structure of L_social M_objects M_contains ‘ the L_double M_negation of themselves and of each L_constituent M_part by the other ’ ( II , 22 ) .

There is , L_therefore , before any L_understanding of L_historic M_agents and M_movements , a L_certain L_aporia in all L_social M_ensembles : from M_afar they may M_appear M_whole , but M_close to , they can be M_seen as M_riddled with M_holes .
This L_increasingly M_comes to L_resemble L_nothing so L_much as L_Sartre 's own M_account of L_History .

In the M_context of the L_negativity of this M_formulation , L_Sartre is L_obliged to L_pose once again the L_problem of whether there can be a L_totalization , without any L_independent L_totalizer or L_totalizing M_force such as the L_dialectic , or whether the M_structure of M_negation that he has L_described M_means that , as for L_Adorno or L_Bakhtin , L_history does not L_develop L_positively but , L_rather , L_negatively , and is L_therefore L_instead L_detotalizing :

L_Marxism is L_rigorously M_true if L_History is L_totalization ; it is not so any more if L_human L_history M_decomposes into a L_plurality of L_particular L_histories , or if , in any L_case , within the M_relationship of L_immanence that L_characterizes M_struggle , the M_negation of each M_adversary by the other is on L_principle L_detotalizing .
L_Certainly , we have neither the M_design nor the L_actual L_possibility of M_showing here the M_full L_truth of L_dialectical L_materialism …

Our M_goal is L_solely to L_establish whether , in a L_practical M_ensemble M_torn M_apart by L_antagonism ( whether there are L_multiple L_conflicts or whether they are M_reduced to one ) the M_breaks themselves are L_totalizing and M_carried M_along by the L_totalizing M_movement of the M_ensemble .

At this M_point L_Sartre M_confronts the L_possibility that the M_whole L_project of the L_Critique , L_stated so L_confidently on its very L_first L_page — ‘ it must be L_proved that a M_negation of a M_negation can be an M_affirmation ’ ( I , 15 ) — may M_break down .
L_perhaps the L_Truth of L_History can not be L_proved ; its M_direction can not be M_discerned .

L_Sartre 's M_reaction to the M_threat that the M_negation of a M_negation may M_produce a L_detotalizing L_effect is to M_introduce a L_new L_category , a L_unifying M_force of a ‘ L_singularization ’ which M_incarnates the L_universal : ‘ If L_totalization L_really is an L_ongoing L_process ’ , he L_writes , ‘ then it M_operates L_everywhere .

That L_means both that there is a L_dialectical L_meaning of the L_practical M_ensemble … and that each L_singular L_event L_totalizes in itself the L_practical M_ensemble in the L_infinite M_richness of its L_singularity ’ ( II , 26 ) .

Unlike Lukács ' L_insignificant L_event from which the L_universal is L_precariously M_drawn out through the L_narrative , L_Sartre 's L_singularity M_works L_synecdochally in a L_conventional L_antinomy with the L_universal , the M_relation between the two M_structured L_according to the M_familiar L_nineteenth-century M_model of M_organic M_growth or L_process in which each L_singular L_event M_makes up the L_whole while , as he M_puts it , ‘ the L_whole is L_entirely L_present in the M_part as its M_present L_meaning and as its L_destiny ’ .

L_Sartre 's ‘ L_singular L_universal ’ , L_therefore , M_begs the L_question , for it is L_predicated on the L_assumption that , if there is not a L_totality as such , then there L_already is an L_overall L_totalization : ‘ If L_totalization L_really is an L_ongoing L_process … ’ .

That L_developing L_process is itself L_totalized through L_Sartre 's M_assertion that each L_totalization is the L_totalization of all M_struggles , as it must be if the L_singular is to M_incarnate the L_universal .
The L_concept of the L_singular L_universal L_thus L_facilitates a L_circularity in the L_argument whereby L_Sartre can M_avoid the L_question which he L_began by L_posing .
So the L_singular L_universal M_presumes the L_totalization he ca n't ( L_yet ) L_prove .

This M_strategy M_marks a M_structure of L_repetition in L_Sartre 's L_text : each L_time he L_poses the L_question of how there can be L_totalization of L_History without a L_totalizer , he M_retreats to a more L_limited L_example whose L_unity is L_already L_evident , but which in the M_end only M_brings him M_back to the L_original L_question again .

In this L_case L_Sartre M_demonstrates how the L_singular L_universal M_works , by M_appealing to the M_concrete L_example of a L_boxing L_match — a L_random L_exemplification that just L_happens to M_reproduce the L_single M_adversaries of the master/slave L_dialectic .
Its L_totalization M_takes L_place through its M_incarnation , as M_part of the L_totality of L_boxing , in the L_overall M_framework within which each L_individual L_fight L_occurs .

Each L_boxing L_match , L_Sartre L_claims , must be both a L_unique L_event and L_also in some M_sense the M_incarnation of all L_boxing , whose M_rules and L_conventions it M_follows , and whose L_past and L_future L_history it M_sets itself against .
But it is L_also L_apparent that that L_totality is not L_completely L_known , nor is its L_future M_shape L_even L_presumed .

By L_totalization , L_therefore , L_Sartre does not here L_mean L_anything like a L_predetermined M_end or L_final M_closure of a L_totality but L_rather a L_process of M_mediation among the M_parts , where each is L_determined by the other .

No L_one can L_predict the L_future of L_boxing , either at the M_level of L_particular M_victories or M_defeats , in L_effect a M_structure of L_repetition , nor at the more L_general M_level of L_possible L_modifications or L_developments of the L_sport .
L_Yet each L_individual L_bout M_articulates itself within the M_framework of the L_history of L_boxing , L_known and L_unknown .
This M_allows L_Sartre to M_include L_chance and L_contingency in his L_scheme .

Since it can not be L_known as a L_concept that will M_realize itself in the L_future , L_Sartre L_argues L_instead that the L_totality only M_produces itself in the L_moment : ‘ The M_incarnation as such is at once L_unrealizable except as L_totalization of L_everything and L_irreducible to a M_pure L_abstract L_unity of that which it L_totalizes ’ ( II , 58 ) .
The L_universal , the L_totality , can only be L_known through the L_singular .
But its L_future M_direction L_remains L_unknown and L_indeterminate .

At the same L_time L_Sartre M_makes a M_larger , though L_less L_persuasive L_claim that the L_boxing-match L_also M_works L_synecdochally and L_re-exteriorizes a more L_fundamental L_violence , L_namely the L_interiorized L_condition of L_scarcity that he M_considers to be the L_basis of L_conflict in L_general .

The L_boxing L_match ‘ is the L_public M_incarnation of all L_conflict ’ ( II , 32 ) , L_totalizing in its own M_struggle the L_whole of ‘ L_contemporary L_irreducibilities and M_fissures ’ ( II , 26 ) :

L_thus one can and must L_say … that each L_fight is the L_singularisation of all the L_circumstances of the L_social L_whole in M_movement and that by this L_singularisation , it M_incarnates the M_enveloping L_totalization which the L_historical L_process is .
But then he L_adds , ‘ I have L_said and I L_repeat that we have not L_yet L_proved that this M_enveloping L_totalization L_exists ’ .

So , although it is L_possible to M_conceive of any L_event as an M_incarnation of the L_totality , L_insofar as it must itself M_make up a M_part of that L_totality in its L_determination , unlike the L_case of the L_boxing L_match , where we can M_define the L_overall L_entity ‘ L_boxing ’ , it L_still L_remains L_unproven that an L_overall L_entity , ‘ L_History ’ , can be L_said to L_exist at all .
For all his L_use of the M_model of the L_boxing L_match , L_Sartre has L_really M_got no further with the L_fundamental L_question of how there can be L_totalization without a L_totalizer .

It is L_simple L_enough for him to M_show that a L_boxing L_match M_takes L_place within a L_general L_totality of ‘ L_boxing ’ , which is itself only L_ever L_present in any L_individual M_incarnation , for as a L_game each L_match is both an L_individual L_bout and L_something M_conducted L_according to L_general M_rules and a L_specific L_social L_tradition .
